EmailTemplate.subject: Guardant Health at ASCO 2016
EmailTemplate.textOnly:
Dr. {!Contact.LastName},
We’re excited to let you know that last week ASCO held a press conference highlighting the results from our podium presentation where we presented data from more than 15,000 Guardant360 patients. It was the largest ever comprehensive liquid biopsy study, and it demonstrated high rates of similarity between the somatic genomic landscape seen in circulating tumor DNA, and that seen in population-scale cancer genomics studies based on tissue samples. ASCO also issued a press release (found here), which resulted in heavy international coverage about liquid biopsies.
The data also showed Guardant360 had very high positive predictive value for driver alterations when compared with matched tissue samples, which helped drive attention and awareness about the value of liquid biopsies as a clinical tool. In case you missed it, here are a few highlights, and I have summarized some of the other coverage for you below:
The New York Times ‘Liquid’ Cancer Test Offers Hope for Alternative to Painful Biopsies By Andrew Pollack, June 4, 2016
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/05/health/liquid-cancer-test-offers-hope-for-alternative-to-painful-biopsies.html
Key quote: “I think this study really demonstrates the veracity of the liquid biopsy approach,” said Philip C. Mack, director of molecular pharmacology at the University of California Davis Comprehensive Cancer Center, who is presenting the results here this weekend to the annual meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology.
Fortune The Cancer Biopsy of the Future Could Be a Simple Blood Test June 5, 2016 http://fortune.com/2016/06/05/asco-guardant-liquid-biopsy/
Key quote: "And the new study results were striking: Common disease-driving mutated genes detected by Guardant360 in breast, lung, colorectal, and other cancers were also present in 94-100% of the solid tissues extracted from trial participants."
Guardant Health also presented data from the first prospective clinical trial evaluating the use of a comprehensive liquid biopsy to guide therapy selection for patients with metastatic cancer. In the words of primary investigator Dr. Jeeyun Lee of the Samsung Medical Center, “the genomic landscape of variants we found with Guardant360 were comparable to what we saw in NEXT-1, a tissue-based prospective clinical utility study. When these patients are then guided to matched therapy based on ctDNA profiling, the response rate was again comparable to what we see when selection is based on tumor specimens." Read the press release here.
In addition, Guardant Health was featured in 13 other poster presentations. Most of them, along with the slides from our 15,000 patient study, are collected here.
I hope you find these helpful. Please contact me at your convenience to discuss how Guardant360 can help your practice.
{!Contact.OwnerFullName}
Washington Post ‘Liquid biopsy’ study offers hope for a blood test to find cancer By Laurie McGinley, June 4, 2016
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/to-your-health/wp/2016/06/04/liquid-biopsy-study-offers-hope-for-blood-test-for-finding-cancer/
Key quote: The results were welcomed by David Nanus, chief of hematology and medical oncology at Weill Cornell Medicine and New York-Presbyterian Hospital. "To be able to draw that information from a blood test is a huge step forward," said Nanus, who wasn't involved with the study.
TIME A Blood Test for Cancer Gets Closer By Alice Park, June 4, 2016 http://time.com/4357037/blood-test-cancer/
Key quote: Says Dr. Julie Vose, professor of internal medicine at the Nebraska Medical Center University Hospital and president of ASCO, “We could imagine this type of assay could be used in the future to surveil patients and change their treatments when new mutations are found, without having to biopsy the original tumor, and in cases of metastatic disease where it may be more costly and dangerous to do that.”
HealthDay Liquid Biopsy May Help Doctors Track Changes in Tumors Large study found it predicted when cancer DNA was mutating, could help tailor treatments to avoid drug resistance By Dennis Thompson, June 4, 2016 https://consumer.healthday.com/cancer-information-5/mis-cancer-news-102/liquid-biopsy-may-help-doctors-track-changes-in-tumors-711659.html
Key quote: Dr. Joshua Brody, director of the Lymphoma Immunotherapy Program at Mount Sinai's Tisch Cancer Institute in New York City, called the research "a big deal. This will be practice-changing."
The Economist The personalisation of cancer treatments is leading to better outcomes for patients June 4, 2016 http://www.economist.com/news/science-and-technology/21700125-it-will-also-pave-way-cures-personalisation-cancer-treatments
Key quote: "If liquid biopsy can be made routine, the clinical consequences will be vast."
